_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Onslow County Water and Sewer Authority (ONWASA)
Jacksonville, North Carolina

Executive Summary - 2005

Since the startup of operations in 1996, ONWASA has implemented a comprehensive program to safely manage chlorine and other chemicals at its two water treatment plants (Hubert WTP and Dixon WTP) located in Onslow County. No reportable chlorine releases have occurred since startup. 

Plant operators have since startup practiced industry standard to safety manage chlorine. Activities included standard operating procedures, two man teams for cylinder changes and a preventative maintenance program. In 2000, the sites upgraded to a full vacuum system to deliver chlorine. This change eliminated a pressure regulator and pressure section of piping reducing the risk of a chorine release. 

Up to the 4th quarter of 2005, ONWASA had maintained an inventory of less than 1,500 pounds of chlorine at each plant through administrative controls. In late 2004, to meet expanding demand, ONWASA realized that higher chlorine addition rates would be required. As a result, the decision was made to increase chlorine inventories to 4,000 pounds at each plant. 

The increased inventories are above the thresholds for compliance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program (1,500 pounds) and the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) and thus would trigger compliance with both regulations.          

To achieve compliance, ONWASA obtained the serviced of an engineering group with extensive PSM and RMP experience. During the period from July to November 2005, the engineering group provided services such as listed below to bring both plants into full PSM and RMP compliance:

?    Compiling Process Safety Information for each site 
?    Conducting and documenting a Process Hazards Analysis for each site
?    Assisting with the development of Standard Operating Procedures
?    Providing RMP, PSM and chlorine safety training
?    Establish a structured Mechanical Integrity program
?    Providing procedures fo

r Management of Change, Contractor Safety, Self Audits, Pre-Start Up Safety Review and other PSM,. RMP elements
?    Developing and imputing data for the electronic RMP submission to the EPA
?    Providing a multi-year calendar which defines key PSM/RMP compliance elements such as Training, Self Audit, SOP Certifications and Process Hazards Analysis 

As a result PSM, PSM information and knowledge provided by the engineering group, ONWASA feels confident that our plants will continue with safe chlorine operations.  

Report by:
                                                               
Kerry O. Randel, Operations Manager

December 10, 2005
